title: Specialist spotters to be deployed in the crowd at England's clash with Bulgaria
text:
Specialist spotters will be deployed for England's Euro 2020 qualifier in Bulgaria to sit among the supporters and report any racist abuse directed towards Gareth Southgate's players.

FARE (Football Against Racism in Europe) are working with UEFA and will have three undercover observers, also known as spotters, inside the Stadion Vasil Levski on Monday.

Part of the stadium will be closed as punishment after Bulgaria fans were found guilty of racist behaviour in previous games against Kosovo and the Czech Republic.

Specialist spotters will be deployed for England's Euro 2020 qualifier in Bulgarian capital Sofia

Amid fears of further abuse - and with Tammy Abraham saying England's players would be willing to walk off the pitch in Sofia - FARE are taking extra precautions.

Each spotter, who will all speak both English and Bulgarian, will be wired into UEFA's match delegate and main observer, reporting any indications of abuse from the stands. He or she can then alert the referee.

Using this tactic solely to spot racism is rare in football. FARE do not send observers to domestic league fixtures and base monitoring international matches on whether they think it represents a high risk of racism. One senior Premier League insider said on Wednesday police forces in England use undercover officers, though primarily to track known troublemakers who are banned but travel to away games.

England's players, who also face the Czech Republic on Friday, walking off the pitch in a united stand against racism would go against UEFA's three-step protocol.

If racist abuse is heard by the referee or reported by a player, then he will request a public announcement over the tannoy system demanding it stop.

Tammy Abraham has said England's players would be willing to walk off the pitch in Sofia

If this fails, then a suspension of play will follow, with both sets of players led off the pitch and a further warning played over the tannoy. If the chants continue, the match can then be abandoned.

Concerns about further abuse comes after black England players were racially abused in their 5-1 win over Montenegro in March. They completed the game, though Raheem Sterling responded to taunts from home fans by pulling on his ears during a goal celebration.

England's trip to Bulgaria coincides with FARE's 'Action Week'. The anti-racism organisation are using this international break to celebrate diversity and campaign against discrimination.

On Monday, 5,000 seats inside the 46,340 Stadion Vasil Levski will be left empty as part of the Bulgarian FA's punishment for racist behaviour. A banner displaying the message '#EqualGame' will be displayed in the closed section.
description: Specialist spotters will be deployed for England's Euro 2020 qualifier in Bulgaria to sit among the supporters and report any racist abuse directed towards Gareth Southgate's players.
